subject: Re: [junit] reg. JUnit
msgSnippet: ... /* * SimpleAdder.java */ public class SimpleAdder { /** Creates a new instance of SimpleAdder */ public SimpleAdder() { } /** adds two integers */ public
messageBody:
Here we go:
------------
/*
* SimpleAdder.java
*/
public class SimpleAdder {

/** Creates a new instance of SimpleAdder */
public SimpleAdder() {
}
/** adds two integers */
public int add(int a,int b) {
return a+b;
}
}

-----------
/*
* SimpleAdderTest.java
* JUnit based test
*/
import junit.framework.*;

public class SimpleAdderTest extends TestCase {

public SimpleAdderTest(java.lang.String testName) {
super(testName);
}
/** Test of add method, of class SimpleAdder. */
public void testAdd() {
SimpleAdder simpleAdder = new SimpleAdder();
assertEquals(simpleAdder.add(4,4),8);
// Add your test code for exceptions, etc
fail("Exceptions not handled. Say for add (null,null), etc");
}

}
------------------

Selva.


> -----Mensaje original-----
> De: pallavi metla [mailto:pallavi28183@...]
> Enviado el: viernes, 12 de septiembre de 2003 6:05
> Para: junit@...
> Asunto: [junit] reg. JUnit
>
>
> Hi everybody,
>
> As a part of my Masters, I am supposed to learn JUnit. I went through some
> of the basic papers as JUnit Test Infected, junit cook book etc. but am not
> understanding the correct use of that.
>
> Like if I create a simple program like addition of two integers and want
> to pass the values of a and b to be some (i.e., generating the test cases),
> how can I do using the JUnit. I created a JUnit program "TestAddInt.java
> "with a testAdd() method in that compared the resultant value of a and b
> with the expected value but its something like I took the values a and b as
> ints..TestAddInt.java but am not understanding how to bring the values of
> the original java program "AddInt.java"??
>
> I am pretty sure that if someone give a simple example, I will learn the
> rest. So I would be thankful if someone helps me out.
>
> Regards,
> Pallavi
